title: 110_hr853
content: The "Wellness and Prevention Act of 2007" may be cited as the short title for this Act. The Congress finds that improving population health and reducing medical costs requires preventive methods. Organizations in the US are calling for more public health professionals. There are only about 6,000 board-certified physicians in preventive medicine. Many healthcare costs are spent on avoidable chronic conditions. The number of preventive medicine programs and students has decreased in recent years. Preventive medicine physicians play a crucial role in serving patients and communities, contributing to a strong public health system. The number of preventive medicine programs and students has decreased in recent years. Loan payment assistance is provided for preventive medicine physicians. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may pay up to $20,000 of medical education loans for eligible preventive medicine physicians who receive board certification in preventive medicine between fiscal years 2008 and 2012. Application for loan payment assistance must be submitted to the Secretary as required. The term "medical education loan" refers to the outstanding principal and interest on a loan for attending a school of medicine. The term "school of medicine" is defined in the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is responsible for carrying out this section. Authorization of Appropriations for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 is provided to carry out this section by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. SEC. 4. WELLNESS PROGRAM EMPLOYER CREDIT. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section for a wellness program employer credit. The wellness program employer credit under section 38 allows eligible employers to receive a credit of 25% of expenses for developing and implementing a qualified wellness program, with a maximum credit of $200 per qualified employee. Eligible employer is defined as an employer meeting certain criteria. The term 'eligible employer' is defined as an employer who develops and implements a qualified wellness program and keeps accurate records of employee participation. A qualified wellness program is one developed and implemented by the employer in consultation with an individual. An eligible employer must implement a wellness program that includes health risk assessments, offers preventive services recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, and provides annual counseling sessions. The employer's wellness program must include annual counseling sessions and seminars on various health topics such as smoking, obesity, stress management, physical fitness, nutrition, substance abuse, depression, mental health, heart disease, and maternal and infant health. Qualified participants must meet certain criteria. The eligible employer's wellness program must have at least 50% of full-time employees as qualified participants. A qualified employee is a full-time employee who participates in the employer's wellness program. A qualified participant for a taxable year must engage in at least 2 annual activities. The eligible employer's wellness program requires at least 50% of full-time employees to participate. A qualified participant must engage in 2 annual activities and undergo a health risk assessment. This section does not apply after December 31, 2012. The wellness program employer credit is added to Section 38(b) of the Code. This amendment includes a new paragraph (32) for the credit. Additionally, the table of sections is updated to include the new item related to the wellness program credit after section 45N. The wellness program participant credit, added as Section 25E, applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. For qualified employees, a $200 tax credit is allowed against the tax imposed for the taxable year. A qualified employee is defined as a full-time employee who is a qualified participant in the employer's wellness program. A qualified participant in a wellness program must engage in at least 2 annual preventive services and undergo a health risk assessment as determined by the employer. The term `qualified wellness program' for eligible employers involves developing and implementing a program that includes health risk assessments and offers at least 2 preventive services recommended by the U.S. Preventive guidelines. The qualified wellness program for eligible employers includes offering annual counseling sessions and seminars related to smoking, obesity, stress management, physical fitness, nutrition, substance abuse, depression, mental health, heart disease, as recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force. The term 'eligible employer' refers to an employer who develops and implements a qualified wellness program, keeps accurate records of preventive services, and has at least 50% of full-time employees participating. The wellness program includes counseling sessions and seminars on various health topics recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force. The section discusses the eligibility criteria for employers to participate in a qualified wellness program, with a requirement for at least 50% of full-time employees to participate. The provision does not apply after December 31, 2012. The amendment under Sec. 25E introduces a wellness program participant credit, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007.
